metadata.title: A metal-honeycomb-type structured catalyst for steam reforming of methane: Effect of preparation condition change on reforming performance

(°C) Conversion (%) Selectivity (%) CO CO2 Ce 550 48.6 24.6 75.4 650 79.1 59.4 40.6 Y 550 46.2 26.6 73.4 650 77.4 54.7 45.3 Mg 550 45.6 25.8 74.2 650 76.9 55.5 44.5 Zr 550 46.6 26.1 73.9 650 76.7 58.8 41.2 None (Al only) 550 44.1 26.8 73.2 650 76.3 56.5 43.5 A metal-honeycomb-type structured catalyst for steam reforming of methane: Effect of preparation condition change on reforming performance Choji Fukuhara ⁎ Kazumasa Yamamoto Yudai Makiyama Wataru Kawasaki Ryo Watanabe Department of Applied Chemistry and Biochemical Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Shizuoka University, 3-5-1 Johoku, Naka-ku, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka 432-8561, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry and Biochemical Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Shizuoka University 3-5-1 Johoku, Naka-ku Hamamatsu Shizuoka 432-8561 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +81 53 478 1171; fax: +81 53 476 0095. Graphical abstract In order to construct a structured steam reforming system, a honeycomb-type nickel-based catalyst was prepared by the combined technique of a sol–gel method and electroless plating on a stainless steel substrate. The type of the reducing agent used in the plating process influenced not only the forming rate of the nickel particles, but also the methane steam reforming (MSR) property of the prepared catalyst. The catalyst prepared using NaBH4 demonstrated a higher performance for MSR than the commercial catalyst, indicating that the catalyst degradation was quite low even under the severe H2O/CH4 condition. The plating time of the nickel plating process also significantly influenced the reforming property. When using the NaBH4 reducing agent, the plating time of about 3min provided the highest performance. The chloride and the sulfate were suitable for the anion species of the nickel reagent used in the plating. Based on the XPS measurement, the electron state of the nickel, which was prepared using the chloride and the sulfate was thought to be a state that is appropriate for the formation of the CHx species and the formation of O* species in the reforming mechanism. Adding a promoter component to the aluminum sol solution was effective for improving the reforming performance. Especially, the reforming property of the catalyst that adds the Ce component was improved. The combination technique developed in this study is a useful and expandable method for preparing the structured catalyst with a high performance on the stainless steel substrate. Keywords Honeycomb-type catalyst Structured catalyst Methane steam reforming Electroless plating Sol–gel method 1 Introduction The steam reforming process of hydrocarbons for a hydrogen production system has been continuously improved for years by developing a high performance catalyst and improving the system efficiency. The reforming process that is currently operating in industry is thought to be a high perfection process as the reactive system. The large-scale steam reforming process with the hydrogen manufacturing ability of a maximum of 100,000Nm3/h is industrially operating [1]. Fig. 1 shows the secular change in the handling capacity of the catalytic reforming process in oil refinery fields around the world [2]. The change in the handling capacity, which is associated with the amount of hydrogen production, shows a remarkable increase in 1994, and shows the tendency that keeps increasing afterwards. Assuming a society based on hydrogen, the amount of hydrogen manufacturing in the large-scale reforming process will significantly increase in the future. On the other hand, in the case of the decentralized hydrogen manufacturing process like the on-site type hydrogen station, development of a novel reforming system, which has some unique properties not found in the large-scale reforming system, would be strongly needed. That is, such unique properties of the reaction system are (1) DSS operation ability, (2) rapid response to load fluctuation, (3) compactness of device, and (4) excellent thermal exchange. The fixed-bed reaction system adopted in the large-scale hydrogen manufacturing process cannot satisfy such properties. Therefore, the development of a novel reforming system based on a different concept from the fixed-bed reaction system is necessary. The structured reaction system which integrates the chemical property (catalytic activity and selectivity) and the physical properties (enhancement of heat-transfer, rectifying property of flow and lower pressure drop) by depositing a catalytic component onto a metallic substrate, which composes the reactor, is a reactive system that satisfies the previous properties. We have investigated the operating performance of such a structured reaction system from the experimental and theoretical viewpoints [3–6]. It was subsequently found that this reaction system enables a rapid response to load fluctuations, effective exchange of heat energy and downsizing of reactor dimensions. The development of the reforming system in which the structured reaction system was adopted would produce an advantage in the construction of a decentralized hydrogen production infrastructure like the on-site type hydrogen station. A common method of preparing the plate-type catalyst and the fin-type catalyst for the structured reaction system is a wash-coat method and a sol–gel method as described in Meille's review [7]. We have focused our attention on an electroless plating technique for easily and uniformly depositing a catalytic component onto a metallic surface [8]. We also have separately prepared a nickel-based catalyst [9–12], a copper-based catalyst [13–16] and a palladium-based catalyst [17] on an aluminum substrate, and investigated their catalytic performances. However, the steam reforming of methane requires the high heat energy of about 600–900°C, and the use of a stainless steel substrate is requested from the viewpoint of heat resistance. When preparing the structured catalyst on a stainless steel substrate, some ideas for the electroless plating are necessary. Because the standard electrode potential of iron is four times nobler than that of aluminum, the deposition of the metallic component having a strong adhesion on a stainless steel substrate is difficult using only the electroless plating technique. We have developed the following novel method for preparing a stainless-honeycomb-type Ni/Al2O3 catalyst; first the formation of an oxide layer on a stainless steel substrate by a sol–gel method, second, a seeding of elemental palladium as a catalyst nuclide for anodic oxidation of reducing agent, and finally the deposition of a nickel component onto the substrate by electroless plating [18]. The prepared honeycomb-type catalyst showed a high performance of methane-steam reforming (MSR), which was almost equal to the equilibrium, and high hydrogen manufacturing ability under the severe condition of 0.6s or less residence time (S.V. based on the net volume of the catalyst layer: 301,500h−1). These results demonstrated that the preparation method developed in our study is effective for preparing a structured catalyst having a high performance for steam reforming. Such a technique for preparing a structured catalyst by the combination of the sol–gel method and the electroless plating is a unique technique from the viewpoint of the catalyst preparation. By optimizing the operating conditions of the electroless plating and the sol–gel method, a further active honeycomb-type catalyst might be prepared. In addition, the degrees-of-freedom of the oxide layer formed by the sol–gel method and that of the metal ion in the electroless plating suggest an attractive application of this combination method to prepare other kinds of structured catalysts. In this study, the MSR performance of the structured Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was initially compared to that of the commercial reforming catalyst under the same reaction conditions in order to clarify the effectiveness of the combination technique of the sol–gel method and the electroless plating. Second, the effects of the plating condition change (kinds of reducing agent, kinds of counter anion of nickel, plating time) and the addition of the promoter element into the structured catalyst were investigated to enhance the reforming performance. It was then found that the structured Ni/Al2O3 catalyst had a higher performance than the commercial catalyst and that the difference in the plating conditions profoundly influenced the reforming property. The construction of the structured reforming system would be realized by using the honeycomb-type catalyst developed in this study. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of metal-honeycomb-type nickel-based catalyst The preparation procedure of the honeycomb-type Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was shown in Fig. 2 [18]. The outline of the preparation procedure is as follows. A ferrite-type stainless honeycomb fin (18mmφ×45mm length, cell density 100cpsi, apparent surface area 250cm2, fin thickness 0.1mm) was used as the metallic honeycomb substrate. After washing and activating with a 6M-HCl solution, the fin substrate was immersed in the aluminum-triisopropoxide sol solution (Al[OCH(CH3)2]3:12g, HNO3 aq.:6mL, HCHO:4mL, H2O:80mL). To uniformly coat the fin surface by the sol, the immersed substrate was slowly raised and was rotated with about 170rpm. After the rotation, the substrate was calcined at 500 °C. The coating and calcination were repeated with three times. In the third calcination, the temperature was at 800°C (ramping time: 1.0h, holding time: 2.0h) to form a γ-alumina layer on its surface. After that, the Pd-Sn alternate plating was performed to deposit the Pd nuclide on the fin surface, which was a catalyst component for the electroless nickel plating on the oxide substrate. The fin substrate was alternately immersed 20 times in the activation liquid (PdCl2: 1.4×10−3 mol/L, HCl aq.: 5.7×10−3 mol/L, 35°C) and the sensitization liquid (SnCl2··2H2O: 1.1×10−3 mol/L, HCl aq.: 5.7×10−3 mol/L, 35°C), thus depositing the Pd nuclide on the fin surface. The nuclide was reduced by 3M-hydrazine. Finally, the substrate was immersed in the nickel plating bath at 55°C to deposit the nickel component onto its surface. Three kinds of nickel plating baths with different reducing agents were used; i.e., a sodium borohydride bath (NiCl2·6H2O:45g/L, NaBH4:0.6g/L, NaOH:20g/L, NH2CH2CH2NH2:60mL/L, 55°C), a trimethylamine-borane bath (NiCl2·6H2O: 45g/L, (CH3)3NBH3: 3g/L, NaOH: 5g/L, C6H5Na3O7·2H2O: 60g/L, 55°C) and a sodium hypophosphite monohydrate bath (NiCl2·6H2O: 45g/L, NaH2PO2·H2O:50g/L, NaOH:5g/L, C6H5Na3O7·2H2O:60g/L, 55°C). The maximum plating time of each nickel bath was 60min. In addition, other structured catalysts were prepared by changing NiCl2·6H2O to NiSO4·6H2O (50g/L) and/or Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (55g/L) in the sodium borohydride bath. 2.2 Performance test of methane steam reforming The methane-steam reforming over the prepared catalyst was conducted at atmospheric pressure using a conventional flow reactor. After the catalyst was reduced at 600°C (ramping time: 1h, holding time: 1h) in a hydrogen stream (100mL/min), methane and water were fed into the reactor. The flow rate of methane was 2.5×10−3–7.5×10−3 mol/min, the ratio of steam to carbon (S/C) 1 or 2, the partial pressure of raw material 0.8atm (diluted by nitrogen), and the reaction temperature 450–650°C. Conversion and product selectivity were calculated on the basis of carbon. Two commercial catalysts (RUA, FCR-2-04L, Clariant Catalysts K.K., granular-type) were used to compare the reforming performance. These catalysts (abbreviated to Catalyst-RUA and Catalyst-FCR) were reduced by hydrogen before the reforming and their performances investigated under the same reforming conditions. 2.3 Characterization of the plated layer The surface morphology of the plated layers were observed using SEM (scanning electron microscopy, JEOL, JSM-7001F). The specific surface areas of the plated catalysts were measured by the BET method (BEL JAPAN, BEL-SORP) using nitrogen at its liquid temperature. The chemical forms of nickel in the plated layer were determined by XPS (X-rays photoelectron spectroscopy, SHIMADZU, ESCA3400). The binding energy was referred to the contaminant carbon (C 1s =284.6eV) for convenience. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Overview and surface morphology of the prepared catalyst Fig. 3 shows an overview and typical surface morphology of the honeycomb-type catalyst prepared using NiCl2·6H2O (nickel source), NaBH4 (reducing agent) and 30-min nickel plating. The catalytic component was uniformly and homogeneously deposited onto the fin substrate using the developed preparation method. Based on the SEM photographs, particles of about 70–150nm in size were formed on the fin substrate. Lathy and jaggy boundary areas were also recognized on the surface of each particle. As predicted from such fine particles, the prepared catalyst had a relatively high specific surface area, which was confirmed by the BET value of 152m2/g. The adhesion of the deposited component was very strong, thus the exfoliation of such a component was not observed after the reforming test. The good adhesion of the formed catalyst layer was confirmed from the SEM observation for a section of the prepared catalyst [18]. The combination technique of the sol–gel method and the electroless plating is suitable as the preparation method for depositing the catalytic component on a stainless steel substrate. 3.2 Reforming property of the prepared Ni-based catalyst compared to the commercial catalyst Fig. 4 shows methane reforming property of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst that was prepared by the combination technique of the sol–gel method and the electroless plating (nickel source: NiCl2·6H2O, reducing agent: NaBH4, 30-min plating), compared to that of two commercial reforming catalysts. For the impartial comparison, the prepared Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was a granular-type catalyst (abbreviated catalyst-EP(p)) which was carefully peeled from the fin substrate and was subsequently grained. The particle diameter of each catalyst was adjusted to 0.25–0.5mmφ, and 0.1g of the catalyst was packed into the reactor with dilution using 0.5g quartz sand. The commercial catalysts were reduced at 700°C because the reforming activity was insufficient when reducing at 600°C. The reduction temperature of the Catalyst-EP(p) was 600°C. As shown in Fig. 4, the Catalyst-FCR did not show any reforming activity at 550°C or less, and showed a little activity at 600°C or more. The reduction temperature of 700°C was not sufficient for the Catalyst-FCR. The Catalyst-RUA including the ruthenium element showed a sufficient activity, which suggested a progressive effect by the noble component on the reforming performance. Such a high performance of the RUA catalyst would promote the making of this catalyst a candidate catalyst in a small hydrogen production system for a fuel cell. On the other hand, the Catalyst-EP(p) showed a higher reforming activity that exceeds the activity of Catalyst-RUA at 550°C or more. When the temperature was set from 650°C to 500°C again, the reforming activity did not decrease, but rather seemed to improve. This catalyst was mainly composed of nickel. Even if the precious and expensive metals are not used, the Catalyst-EP(p) having a high reforming activity is interesting from the viewpoint of the catalyst preparation. As shown in Table 1 , the product selectivity of the Catalyst-EP(p) and the Catalyst-RUA was almost the same. Table 2 shows a part of the physicochemical property of these catalysts. Two commercial catalysts use the α-type Al2O3 support having a small surface area to provide heat resistance of the catalyst, thus the specific surface areas of these catalysts are quite low. On the other hand, the specific surface area of the Catalyst-EP(p) of which the substrate is γ-type Al2O3 is very high. It is well known that the steam reforming of methane progresses by the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) type mechanism. Therefore, a high surface area of the Catalyst-EP(p) was thought to be one of the factors that had a positive effect on the reforming performance. Fig. 5 represents the durability performance test of the reforming property over the honeycomb type Ni-based catalyst (abbreviated Catalyst-EP) that was prepared on the fin substrate by the sol–gel method and the electroless plating (nickel source: NiCl2·6H2O, reducing agent: NaBH4, 30-min plating). The net weight of the catalyst component (mainly nickel and aluminum) deposited onto the fin-substrate was 0.33g. The reforming activity of the structured catalyst did not have any change in deterioration during the 120-h durability test under the S/C=2 condition. The hydrogen production and the selectivity of CO and CO2 were also maintained. The reforming test was shut down at 120hours, but was restarted again under the severe condition of S/C=1 after the hydrogen-reduction of the catalyst. The stability of the reforming performance of the structured catalyst was still maintained during the examination at about 24h. In general, for an industrial steam reforming process that uses the nickel-based catalyst, excessive steam is supplied to the reforming area in order to avoid catalyst deactivation by the carbon deposition. Such an excessive supply of steam raises the running cost of the process operation. The maintenance of a stable reforming property shown in Fig. 5 would lead to a cost reduction of the process operation by reducing the steam use. The Catalyst-EP has an interesting feature from the viewpoint of a steady reforming property though the life test at longer times is necessary. No remarkable carbon deposition was observed on the catalyst surface after the reforming. Thus, the Catalyst-EP showed a reforming activity not inferior to the RUA catalyst and its reforming property was stable under the severe S/C condition. In order to prepare a novel structured catalyst, the combination technique of the sol–gel method and the electroless plating is effective and interesting. The effect of the preparation condition changes to the sol–gel method and the electroless plating on the reforming performance is investigated in the next section. 3.3 Effect of types of reducing agents in the plating bath For the methane steam reforming over the nickel-based catalyst loaded onto an oxide substrate, such as alumina, the reaction mechanism that makes CHx species and O* species as the intermediates, which are formed by dissociative adsorption of methane and by the activation of steam, has been proposed by many researchers [19–25]. The reaction steps are represented by Eqs. (1)–(6) in which, * is an active site, and n is the number of active sites necessary to activate the methane. <Methane activation step> (1) CH 4 + n * = CH x − n * + ( 4 − x ) 2 H 2 ( x : 0,1,2,3 ) <Steam activation step> (2) H 2 O + 2 * = OH − * + H − * (3) OH − * + * = O − * + H − * (4) H 2 O + * = O − * + H 2 <Reaction and production steps> (5) CH x − n * + O − * = CO + X 2 H 2 + ( n + 1 ) * (6) 2 H − * = H 2 + 2 * The formation of the CHx species in Eq. (1) proceeds on the nickel site, while that of the OH−* species by Eq. (2) chiefly proceeds on the oxide support. The OH−* species then migrates to the nickel element over the oxide support, and produces the O−* species by Eq. (3). The O−* species is also directly produced by Eq. (4) on the nickel element. Finally, the reforming products are generated by the reaction between the CHx species and the O−* species on the nickel site, including the coupling of the H−*. Naturally, because the CHx species, the OH−* species, and the O−* species are generated on the nickel surface and the substrate surface, the forming condition of the nickel component on the substrate would have a profound effect on such reforming steps. The type of reducing agent in the nickel plating process is one of the factors that affect the forming condition of the nickel component. The effects of the different kinds of reducing agents on the forming state of the nickel component and on the reforming property were investigated in this section. Fig. 6 shows the surface morphology change of the deposited particles concerning the catalyst, which were prepared using different reducing agents, NaH2PO2·NaBH4, and (CH3)3NBH3, versus the plating time. From the XPS measurement of our previous study, it was clarified that the Pd nuclide was formed on the aluminum substrate by the alternate Pd-Sn plating and that the nickel component was plated around the Pd nuclide by the anodic oxidation of the reducing agent. Namely, the growing particle observed in Fig. 6 was mainly the growth of the nickel particle. Based on these figures, the difference in the reducing agent has exerted a significant influence on the growth rate and shape of the particles. Fig. 7 represents the relationship between the plating time and the average particle size estimated from the size data of Fig. 6. The growth rate of the nickel particles was clearly different by the difference in the used reducing agent. The particle growth rate when using NaH2PO2 was considerably fast, and the surface of the Al2O3 base was completely covered by the nickel particle layer within 2–5min. In case of (CH3)3NBH3, the particle growth speed was slow, and the nickel particle coverage at 30min was sparse on the surface. Although the particle was finally distributed over the whole surface after 60min, the particle diameter was quite small compared to that using NaH2PO2. On the other hand, when using NaBH4, the growth rate of the particle was an intermediate value that was between NaH2PO2 and (CH3)3NBH3. The surface morphology of the particle was lathy and included jaggy boundary areas which were quite different from that using the other reducing agents. The BET specific surface area was 152m2/g-deposited of S(NaBH4, 30min), 121m2/g-deposited of S((CH3)3NBH3, 60min) and 63.6m2/g-deposited of S(NaH2PO2, 20min). These results corresponded to the SEM observations. Such a different condition of the deposited nickel particle was caused by a difference in the condition of the electron discharge of the reducing agent. The anode oxidations of each reducing agent are as follows: (7) NaH 2 PO 2 : H 2 P O 2 − + OH − → H 2 P O 3 − + 1 / 2 H 2 + e − (8) NaBH 4 : B H 4 − + 4 OH − → B O 2 − + 2 H 2 O + 2 H 2 +4e − (9) ( CH 3 ) 3 NBH 3 ) : ( CH 3 ) 3 NBH 3 + 4 OH − → ( CH 3 ) 3 N + B O 2 − + 2 H 2 O + 3 / 2 H 2 + 3 e − The electron discharging condition progressing by these equations depended on the plating temperature, the pH of the bath and the component and concentration of the agent used in the plating bath. Such a difference in the electron discharging condition affected the deposition condition of the nickel element and would produce the surface morphology change shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 8 shows the MSR properties of the structured catalysts prepared using the various reducing agents (plating time; NaH2PO2: 20min, NaBH4: 30min, (CH3)3NBH3: 60min). Although each prepared catalyst indicated some high reforming performance, the reforming property was affected by the difference in the reducing agent used in the plating bath. The activity of the catalyst prepared by the sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2) bath was the lowest of the three catalysts, and that of the catalyst prepared by the trimethylamine-borane ((CH3)3NBH3) bath was almost equal to the equilibrium conversion on the high-temperature side, but slightly low on the low-temperature side. On the other hand, the catalyst prepared by the sodium borohydride (NaBH4) bath had the highest activity, producing a large amount of hydrogen from the low temperature side, and almost reached the equilibrium conversion at each reaction temperature. The net weight of the catalyst component (mainly nickel and alumina) deposited on the fin-substrate was 0.33g of Wcat(NaBH4), 0.32g of Wcat((CH3)3NBH3) and 0.55g of Wcat(NaH2PO2). Thus, the order of the catalyst weights did not correspond to the order of the reforming activity. The product selectivity of each catalyst was roughly corresponded to the equilibrium data. Fig. 9 shows the relationship between the CO selectivity and the reforming activity at 500°C and 550°C, which were in a region away from the equilibrium value. The activity and the CO selectivity were in a proportional relation which did not depend on the kind of reducing agent used in the plating process. Fig. 10 shows the XRD profiles of the various catalysts after the reforming. In the catalyst that was prepared by using NaH2PO2, the formation of the Ni3P species was confirmed besides the nickel species. It is generally known that when using the NaH2PO2, the phosphorus of the reducing agent component mixes into the plating layer and that the Ni3P species was formed. On the other hand, in the XRD profiles of NaBH4 and (CH3)2NBH3, only the nickel species and the alumina species were confirmed. These results suggested that the quality of the formed nickel species was almost the same regardless of the kind of reducing agent and that the deposited phosphorus species when using NaH2PO2 did not influence the selectivity of the reforming product. 3.4 Effect of plating condition using NaBH4 The NaBH4 was thought to be suitable for the reducing agent in the nickel plating bath for preparing the reforming catalyst. In this section, we investigated the effects of the other plating parameters of the nickel bath on the reforming property of the structured catalyst. Because the activity of the prepared honeycomb-type catalyst was close to the equilibrium conversion as shown in Fig. 8, the reforming test in this section was evaluated in a reactive zone away from the equilibrium conversion by using a plate substrate with the small apparent surface area of 40cm2 and increasing the methane feed rate (7.5×10−3 mol/min). Fig. 11 represents the effect of the plating time of the nickel bath on the reforming performance of the prepared catalyst. Fig. 12 is SEM photographs of the surface particle of each catalyst shown in Fig. 11. From these figures, the catalyst only prepared by the alternate Pd-Sn plating, that is, without the nickel plating (plating time: 0min), did not have any reforming activity. However, the catalyst prepared by the plating time of 1.0min or more had some activity, and the formation of the nickel particle could be clearly confirmed since this plating time. The reforming activity of the catalyst that was prepared by the plating time from 1.5min to 3.0min was high. The nickel particle formed on the surface grew as the plating time proceeded, and such a particle growth would demonstrate the improvement of the reforming activity, while, the activities for the 5.0-min and 30-min plating slightly decreased compared to that of the 3-min plating. The weight percent of the catalyst component (mainly nickel component) deposited onto the fin-substrate was 1.3wt% of Wcat(plating time: 1.0min), 4.4wt% of Wcat(1.5min), 11.1wt% of Wcat(3.0min) and 26.7wt% of Wcat(30min). The order of the weight percent of the deposited component would correspond to the change in the nickel particle in the SEM observations. Judging from the result of the reforming activity, however, the change in the amount of the nickel component did not directly produce the progression of the reforming performance. In the previous section, it was mentioned that the methane steam reforming over the supported Ni-based catalyst proceeds by the L–H type mechanism ((1)–(6)) which is composed of the reaction between the CHx species and O* species. This suggests that the condition between the metal site and the substrate is one of the important factors for constructing the reforming site. From the results of Figs. 11 and 12, the excess deposition of the nickel component and the change in its particle size were not proportional to an improvement in the reforming activity. During the formation of the nickel site by the electroless plating, it has been understood that there is an appropriate amount of nickel deposition. In addition, the concentration variation of NaBH4 in the plating bath also influenced the reforming property of the plated catalyst (data not shown). That is, a change in the NaBH4 concentration increased the number of electrons discharged by the anodic oxidation of the reducing agent and accelerated the deposition rate of the nickel component. An excessive change in the concentration, however, produced an increase in the amount of the deposited nickel, which would reduce the reforming activity. There was also an optimum value of the NaBH4 concentration as well as the plating time. Fig. 13 and Table 3 show the effect of the different counter anion species in the nickel plating bath on the reforming property. The reforming activity and the selectivity of the catalyst prepared using sulfate ions was almost the same as that prepared using chlorine ions, while the catalyst prepared using the nitrate ions had little activity. The product selectivity of this catalyst was slightly different from the catalysts prepared using sulfate ions and chlorine ions. Fig. 14 shows the XPS spectra of Ni2p3/2 for these catalysts. All samples were etched by argon ions (accelerating voltage: 2kV, partial pressure: 5×10−4 Pa, etching time: 30s) before the measurement. The electronic state of the Ni element was different due to the difference in the counter anion species. Namely, the electronic state of the nickel for the catalyst that was prepared using the chlorine ions and the sulfate ions corresponded to Ni0 species (852.3eV) and Ni2+ species (855.6eV, 855.8eV), and that for the catalyst prepared using the nitrate ions suggested no Ni0 species, but only Ni2+ species (854.2eV, 857.5eV) [26–32]. Considering such results and the L–H type mechanism represented by Eqs. (1)–(6), it was postulated that the catalyst prepared using the chlorine ions and the sulfate ions offers a convenient surface condition for the formation of the CHx species on the nickel and the formation of O* species with a moderate bonding strength after reducing the catalyst, while over the catalyst prepared using nitrate ions, the surface reaction with the CHx species and O* species generated in the reforming would not smoothly proceed because the bonding strength between the O* species and the nickel is high. In addition, the small amount of Ni0 species on its surface predicts a disadvantage for the formation of the CHx species in the reforming. Although the effect of the counter anion species on the electronic state of the deposited nickel is not clear, it was thought that the nickel component with the electronic state that is suitable for the reforming mechanism was formed on the catalyst that was prepared using the chloride ions and the sulfate ions. 3.5 Effect of promoter element added to aluminum layer The addition of the promoter element is effective as one of the methods for enhancing the performance of the reforming site. For the preparation technique developed in this study, to add the promoter element during the process of preparing the aluminum sol might be an effective method. Table 4 shows the reforming properties of the various structured catalysts that were prepared by adding the promoter-containing reagents, such as Ce(NH4)2(NO3)5·2H2O, ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O, Y(NO3)2·6H2O, and Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, to the aluminum sol. A ferrite-type stainless honeycomb fin (18mmφ×45mm length, cell density 100 cpsi) was used as the honeycomb substrate again. The added amount of the promoter element in the sol was Al:element=10:1 (mol-base). Other preparation procedures, such as the sol-coating, the alternately plating and the electroless plating were the same as that of the non-promoted catalyst. The strong adhesion of the aluminum layer was still maintained after the promoter addition. The addition of the promoter element affected the reforming performance of the structured catalyst. Especially, the activity of the Ce added catalyst showed the improvement of several % at each temperature versus that of the non-added catalyst. Adding the promoter element to the alumina sol solution had the effect of improving the catalytic performance, though the change in the activity was minimal. The product selectivity also slightly changed. The Ce-added catalyst also had a positive effect on the carbon deposition tolerance. Fig. 15 shows the reforming activities of the Ce added catalyst and the non-added catalyst under the condition of S/C=2 at temperatures from 450 to 600°C, and also shows the durability performance of these catalysts under the severe condition of S/C=1 at an 800°C constant temperature after the 280min reaction time. The improvement of the activity of the Ce-added catalyst was clear at 550°C or more compared to that of the non-added catalyst. The Ce added catalyst did not represent the activity deterioration even under a severe condition of 800°C and S/C=1 that accelerates the catalyst deactivation. From the TG (thermogravimetry) analysis, the amount of the deposited carbon after 880h onto the Ce-added catalyst was 0.12 (g/g-cat.), and that onto the non-added catalyst was 1.03 (g/g-cat.). The amount of the deposited carbon has decreased about 1/10 by adding the Ce element. A small amount of the deposited carbon would suggest the possibility of maintaining the stable reforming activity for a long time. It was thought that the addition of the Ce element, which is compatible with oxygen, promotes the oxidation of the carbon species, and that decreases the carbon deposition. The reforming property of the structured catalyst could be further improved by optimizing the Ce addition conditions. 4 Conclusion A nickel-based honeycomb-type catalyst was prepared using the combined technique of the sol–gel method and the electroless plating on the stainless steel substrate. The honeycomb catalyst prepared by using NaBH4 demonstrated a higher methane steam reforming performance than the commercial catalyst. The reducing agent, the plating time and the counter anion of the nickel source used in the nickel plating process significantly influenced the reforming property of the structured catalyst. The reason for such a performance change would be produced by the structural condition of the deposited nickel particle and by the electron state change of the nickel element. The addition of the promoter into the aluminum sol solution had the effect of improving the reforming property. Acknowledgment This research was supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number 22360330. coredata.dc:description: In order to construct a structured steam reforming system, a honeycomb-type nickel-based catalyst was prepared by the combined technique of a sol–gel method and electroless plating on a stainless steel substrate. The type of the reducing agent used in the plating process influenced not only the forming rate of the nickel particles, but also the methane steam reforming (MSR) property of the prepared catalyst. The catalyst prepared using NaBH4 demonstrated a higher performance for MSR than the commercial catalyst, indicating that the catalyst degradation was quite low even under the severe H2O/CH4 condition. The plating time of the nickel plating process also significantly influenced the reforming property. When using the NaBH4 reducing agent, the plating time of about 3min provided the highest performance. The chloride and the sulfate were suitable for the anion species of the nickel reagent used in the plating. Based on the XPS measurement, the electron state of the nickel, which was prepared using the chloride and the sulfate was thought to be a state that is appropriate for the formation of the CHx species and the formation of O* species in the reforming mechanism. Adding a promoter component to the aluminum sol solution was effective for improving the reforming performance. Especially, the reforming property of the catalyst that adds the Ce component was improved. The combination technique developed in this study is a useful and expandable method for preparing the structured catalyst with a high performance on the stainless steel substrate.
coredata.dc:title: A metal-honeycomb-type structured catalyst for steam reforming of methane: Effect of preparation condition change on reforming performance
